sn35.155:4.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …
sn35.155:4.4: How is a Dharma speaker defined?”
sn35.155:5.1: “If a mendicant teaches Dharma for disillusionment with the eye, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dharma’.
sn35.155:5.2: If they practice for disillusionment with the eye, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
sn35.155:5.3: If they’re freed without grasping by disillusionment with the eye, by its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.
sn35.155:5.4: If a mendicant teaches Dharma for disillusionment with the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.155:5.5: mind, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dharma’.
sn35.155:5.6: If they practice for disillusionment with the mind, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
sn35.155:5.7: If they’re freed without grasping by disillusionment with the mind, by its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”
